{{Orphan|date=June 2015}} A history of Native American rhetorics. ==Timeline== '''1823 - [[Johnson v. McIntosh]]'''
:Precedent-setting case between two white parties about property rights to land in America--no Native speaks, though Native interests are affected by the ruling. '''1830s - [[William Apess|William Appess]]'''
:who delivers “An Indian’s Looking-Glass for the White Man” and Eulogy on King Philip
in which he states, “And while you ask yourself, ‘What do they, the Indians, want?’ you have only to look at the unjust laws made for them and say, ‘They want what I want.’” '''1827 and 1839 - Cherokee constitutions'''
'''1879 - [[Thomas Tibbles]]'''
:who arranges an East coast lecture tour for the Ponca leader, Standing Bear. '''1879 - [[Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins]]'''
:who lectures to criticize Agency mistreatment of Paiutes. '''1881 - Constitution of the [[Osage Nation]]'''
:The Osage constitutional democratic government is not recognized after 1898 by the U.S.; the cause is taken up again (with mixed results) throughout the twentieth century until it is finally ended in 1997. See Warrior, The People and the Word. '''1881 – [[Helen Hunt Jackson]], A Century of Dishonor'''
:“The first pro-Indian book to make a significant impact on the American reading public” ( Frederick W. Turner, “The Century after ‘A Century of Dishonor:’”) :An appeal to the heart and conscience of the American people for repairing broken treaties, theft, and institutional termination. '''1928 – [[Meriam Report]]'''
:Institute for Government Research report that denounces the Dawes Act, and criticizes the BIA. '''1946 - [[Indian Claims Commission]] created'''
'''1953 – [[Thomas Banyacya]]'''
:who writes a letter on behalf of the Hopi to President Dwight D. Eisenhower to request recognition for their claims for being conscientious objectors. Mr. Banyacya helped win an understanding with local Selective Service officials that any Hopi who requested classification as a conscientious objector would receive it. '''1955 - [[Tee-Hit-Ton Indians v. United States]]'''
'''1961 - The American Indian Chicago Conference'''
:Ninety separate communities meet at the U Chicago to critique US termination policies, and draft the Declaration of Indian Purpose. '''1966-1995 - Blackbird Bend litigation'''
:In a long and bitter series of legal battles, the Omaha nation seek to regain land along the edge of their reservation. They regain a small amount. See Scherer, Imperfect Victories. '''1969 - Alcatraz Occupation'''
:Mobilized by ethnic studies programs at San Francisco State and UC Berkeley, Bay Area Indians allied with the [[American Indian Movement]] (AIM) occupy Alcatraz island, invoking the Fort Laramie treaty of 1868 for surplus federal land to claim it for a cultural center. '''1970 - [[N. Scott Momaday]]'''
:who gives “Man Made of Words” keynote at the First Convocation of American Indian Scholars. See Warrior, The People and the Word. '''1973 - [[Maria Campbell]]'''
:who publishes Halfbreed, the first book by a Native Canadian women since the death of Pauline Johnson in 1913. '''1977 - Charles Aubid'''
:who testifies before US District Court Judge Miles Lord. Aubid appeals to use the memory of the deceased Old John Squirrel in a case about Anishinaabeg control of the annual wild rice harvest. (Vizenor, “Aesthetics of Survivance,” Survivance: Narratives of Native Presence). '''1980 - [[Russell Means]] “Fighting Words on the Future of the Earth,” ''Mother Jones'''''
:Means critiques Marxism and calls for Lakota tradition. Importantly, he does so through the writing of someone who has recorded his speech. '''1994 - [[Gerald Vizenor]] ''Manifest Manners'''''
:Vizenor formulates the concept of cultural [[survivance]]--survival and resistance--to describe Native signification. '''1997 - U.N. Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples'''
'''1997 - [[Delgamuukw v. British Columbia]]'''
:The Supreme Court of Canada gave greater weight to oral history as a form of legal evidence. '''1997 - Robin Ridington and Dennis Hastings, ''Blessing for a Long Time'''''
:Ridington and Hastings write an ethnography of Umon’hon’ti, which involves them in the story of the subject they document. They work with the Omaha to return their sacred pole from the Harvard Peabody Museum. '''1998 - “Statement of Reconciliation”'''
:which Canada makes to its Native peoples, collected within Gathering Strength, Canada’s Aboriginal Action Plan. '''2005 - Statement on Native American Languages in the College and University Curriculum: MLA Committee on the Literatures of People of Color in the United States and Canada'''
:{{jstor|25595817}} '''2007 - [[Ward Churchill]]'''
:who is fired from Colorado University for allegations of plagiarism after publishing “"Some People Push Back": On the Justice of Roosting Chickens” (2001){{dubious|date=January 2013}} '''2008 - Malea Powell, “Dreaming Charles Eastman: Cultural Memory, Autobiography, and Geography in Indigenous Rhetorical Histories”'''
:A short mixed-genre (narrative, theory, poetry) essay in which Powell grapples with being “an Indian talking about what it means to be an Indian engaged in the archive, what it means to be the object looking back, the objectified engaged in the process of making knowledge about the processes that led to my objectification” (117). ==Bibliography== [[Joni Adamson|[1]]]Adamson, Joni. “Cultural Critique and Local Pedagogy: A Reading of Louise Erdrich’s Tracks.” ''American Indian Literature, Environmental Justice, and Ecocriticism: The Middle Place''. Tucson: U of Arizona P, 2001. 89-115. Print.
Deloria, Philip J. ''Playing Indian''. New Haven: Yale UP, 1998. Print.
Kovach, Margaret. ''Indigenous Methodologies: Characteristics, Conversations, and Contexts''. Toronto: U of Toronto P, 2009. Print.
LaDuke, Winona. ''The Winona LaDuke Reader: A Collection of Essential Writings''. Stillwater: Voyageur, 2002. Print.
Lyons, Scott Richard. “Rhetorical Sovereignty: What Do American Indians Want from Writing?” ''College Composition and Communication'' 51.3 (Feb. 2000): 447-468. JSTOR. Web. 9 Nov. 2011. PDF File.
---, Scott Richard. “There's No Translation for It: The Rhetorical Sovereignty of Indigenous Languages.” ''Cross-Language Relations in Composition''. Ed. Bruce Horner, Min-Zhan Lu, and Paul Kei Matsuda. Carbondale: Southern Illinois UP, 2010.
---, Scott Richard. ''X-Marks: Native Signatures of Assent''. Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 2010. Print.
Mihesuah, Devon Abott, and Angela Cavender Wilson, eds. ''Indigenizing the Academy: Transforming Scholarship and Empowering Communities''. Lincoln: U of Nebraska P, 2004. Print.
---. ''American Indians: Stereotypes & Realities''. Atlanta: Clarity P, 1996. Print.
---. ''So You Want to Write about American Indians?: a Guide for Writers, Students, and Scholars''. Lincoln: U of Nebraska P, 2005. Print.

Powell, Malea. “Dreaming Charles Eastman: Cultural Memory, Autobiography, and Geography in Indigenous Rhetorical Histories.” ''Beyond the Archives: Research as a Lived Process''. Ed. Gesa E. Kirsch and Liz Rohan. Carbondale: Southern Illinois UP, 2008. Print.
---. “Learning (Teaching) to Teach (Learn).” ''Relations, Locations, Positions: Composition Theory for Writing Teachers''. Ed. Peter Vandenberg, Sue Hum, and Jennifer Clary-Lemon. Urbana: National Council of Teachers of English, 2006. 571-580. Print.
---. “Stories Take Place.”
Scherer, Mark R. ''Imperfect Victories: The Legal Tenacity of the Omaha Tribe, 1945-1995''. Lincoln: U of Nebraska P, 1999.
Smith, Paul Chaat and Robert Allen Warrior. ''Like a Hurricane: the Indian Movement from Alcatraz to Wounded Knee''. New York: New P, 1996. Print.

Warrior, Robert. ''The People and the Word: Reading Native Nonfiction''. Minneapolis: U of Minnesota P, 2005. Print.

'''Phum Snay''' ({{lang-km| ភូមិ ស្នាយ}}) is an [[Iron Age]] archaeological site discovered in May 2000 in Preah Neat Prey District, [[Banteay Meanchey Province]], Northwest [[Cambodia]], around {{convert|80|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from the temple ruins of [[Angkor]]. The site was excavated between 2001 and 2003 by primary excavators Dougald O’Reilly of the [[Australian National University]], Pheng Sitha and Thuy Chanthourn. The excavation was intended to discover more about Iron Age life in Cambodia.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/phum-snay-ruined-other-sites-danger | title = Phum Snay ruined, other sites in danger | publisher = The Phnom Penh Post | date=April 25, 2003 |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref>
==Discovery== The site was discovered in 2000 during roadworks, that linked Phum Snay village with National Road 6. Investigations revealed the presence of a number of ancient burials associated with material including bronzes and semiprecious stones. Immediate widespread looting by the local inhabitants over an area of {{convert|24|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} made a full assessment of the extent of the archaeological remains difficult. Excavations started in February 2001 on a 15 x 5 m area.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.academia.edu/460955/Excavations_at_Phum_Snay_Cambodia | title = A Preliminary Report on the Excavation of a Late Prehistoric Cemetery in NorthwestCambodia | publisher = Academia | date= |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref>
== Chronology == The site dates roughly between 500 BC and AD 500.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://hl-128-171-57-22.library.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/17251/1/AP-v45n2-189-211.pdf | title = Archaeology and Archaeozoology of Phum Snay: A late Prehistoric cemetery in Northwestern Cambodia | publisher = ScholarSpace | date= |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cuhk.edu.hk/ics/ccaa/en/talk22.htm | title = Prehistoric Culture of Cambodia and Its Relationship towards South China - all the findings can be placed in frame of VII century BC - V century AD, though I think, that the majority of the finds belong to the beginning of AD era | publisher = The Chinese University of Hong Kong | date=May 16, 2007 |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref> These dates were not obtained from [[stratigraphy]] as many of the artifacts and burials were disturbed by [[looting]].<ref>Oxenham, M., & Tayles, N. (Eds.). (2006). Bioarchaeology of Southeast Asia (Vol. 43). Cambridge University Press.</ref> Chronology was therefore determined by comparison to other nearby sites with similar grave goods and mortuary rituals.
== Human remains == A general analysis was done of the 134 individuals identified through the [[Minimum number of individuals|minimum number of individuals method]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.researchgate.net/figure/269337416_fig7_Figure-7-Archaeological-evidence-of-warfare-and-weaponry-at-Phum-Snay-a-adult-male | title = Figure 7. Archaeological evidence of warfare and weaponry at Phum Snay - The minimum number of individuals (MNI) was 134: 124 adults and 10 sub-adults | publisher = research gate | date= |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref> Twenty-one burials in total were exhumed that contained human remains. The researchers noted pathological lesions in photos and written descriptions. A few specimens were x-rayed but the images yielded limited results. The majority of the injuries listed were cranial lesions. These were categorized into two groups: those caused by sharp force trauma (henceforth referred to SFT) which left small focused circles or lines and those caused by [[blunt force trauma]] (BFT,) resulting in round depressions in the scalp. SFT lesions are generally caused by sharp edged weapons, such as knives, swords and axes. Projectiles, such as arrows or those used by a slingshot should also be considered as SFT objects or items. BFT lesions result from clubs, cudgels and hammers. Perimortem injuries were identified as separate from healed injuries because they often had bone flakes adhered to the edges of the fractures. Researchers were careful to distinguish between lesions caused by violence and those caused by infectious disease.
== Results ==
===Traumatic lesions===
Out of the sample discovered at Phum Snay, 23.4% of the individuals showed signs of traumatic lesions, a number that is much higher than any other site in [[Southeast Asia]].<ref name="domett">Domett, K. M., O'Reilly, D. J. W., & Buckley, H. R. (2011). Bioarchaeological evidence for conflict in Iron Age north-west Cambodia. Antiquity, 85(328).</ref> Both BFT and SFT were present within the skeletal remains, but there was a much higher rate of healed lesions than perimortem lesions.<ref name="domett" /> Some individuals had more than one lesion present upon the cranium. Within a sample of fifteen individuals, seventeen BFT lesions could be seen. These BFT lesions were rounded in shape, ranging in diameter from roughly 4 to 22 mm.<ref name="domett" /> Estimations suggest that injuries acquired by the individuals at the site were much higher than the remains can represent because a majority of assaults probably caused soft-tissue injuries, which would not be preserved in the archaeological record.<ref name="domett" />
===Burials===
Within the Phum Snay site, two types of burials were found. These include bodies that were stretched out lying flat and pits where remains were simply in piles.<ref name="lapteff">Lapteff, S. V. (2013). Early Iron Age Burial Practices of the Ancient Khmer People: The Phum Snay Necropolis, Northwestern Cambodia. Archaeology, Ethnology and Anthropology of Eurasia, 41(2), 137-145.</ref> The burials contained a variety of grave goods, including ceramic vessels, bronze ornaments (bangles, rings, and bells), and a large quantity of animal bones.<ref>O'Reilly, D. J., von den Driesch, A., & Voeun, V. (2006). Archaeology and archaeozoology of Phum Snay: a late prehistoric cemetery in northwestern Cambodia. Asian Perspectives, 45(2), 188-211.</ref><ref>Glover, I., & Bellwood, P. S. (Eds.). (2004). Southeast Asia: from prehistory to history. New York: RoutledgeCurzon.</ref> The proportion of left forelimbs of hooved animals suggest a very particular sacrificial practice of animals within the burials. Researchers found that the manner of the burials and the goods contained within were closest in relation to the [[Óc Eo]] culture of the [[Mekong Delta]].<ref name="lapteff" />
===Weapons===
Another major find within Phum Snay was the high percentage of burials containing weapons. The graves contained swords, daggers, spearheads, and projectile points.<ref name="domett" /> Due to the context of burials with high rates of traumatic lesions, the presence of these weapons indicates possible military formation, and certainly an increased level of violence than is seen in other sites within Southeast Asia. The weapons and tools found within the site were made of iron with bronze adornments.<ref name="lapteff" /> This solidified the site's place within the Iron Age because iron weapons and tools had many advantages over bronze, such as the high abundance of iron within the Earth, which made the spread of iron very rapid.<ref>Kipfer, B. A. (2007). Dictionary of artifacts. Malden, MA: Blackwell Publishing</ref> Also present in the burials of a number of young adult males were [[epaulette|ornamental shoulder decorations]], which further support the idea of a violence-oriented society.<ref name="domett" /> The lack of blunt objects within the burials is slightly puzzling due to the higher rate of BFT lesions than SFT lesions, but this could be explained if the individuals at Phum Snay wore helmets for protection.<ref name="domett" />
===Health===
The health of the people living at Phum Snay was also determined from the burials. Rates of [[attrition (dental)|attrition]], caries, and abscesses in the teeth of the human remains gave an idea of their dietary habits. The main result from the dentition was the presence of a social structure regarding male and female roles within the community. Rates of [[dental caries]] in females were higher than the males, which may be attributed to a sexual division of labor.<ref>Domett, K. M., & O'Reilly, D. J. W. (2009). Health in Pre-Angkorian Cambodia: a bioarchaeological analysis of the skeletal remains from Phum Snay. Asian Perspectives, 48(1), 56-78.</ref> If the men are out hunting, they are receiving a higher level of protein in the food they are consuming, while the females may be eating more cariogenic foods if they are back tending the fields and surrounded by [[starches]] and [[carbohydrates]].
===Morphological comparisons===
Measurements were taken on the cranial and dental morphologies of the individuals found within Phum Snay to compare them with those of modern [[Cambodia]], [[Vietnam]], [[Thailand]], and [[Laos]].<ref name="mats">Matsumura, H., Domett, K. M., & O'REILLY, D. J. (2011). [https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/ase/119/1/119_100511/_article On the origin of pre-Angkorian peoples: perspectives from cranial and dental affinity of the human remains from Iron Age Phum Snay, Cambodia]. Anthropological Science, 119(1), 67-79.</ref> The morphological similarities were found from Q-mode correlation coefficients of cranial and dental metrics.<ref name="mats" /> The findings indicated that the morphology of individuals at Phum Snay were significantly different than any of the other groups being compared. Overall, the modern groups have less robusticity than is found in the Phum Snay morphologies.<ref name="mats" /><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.cambodiadaily.com/archives/pre-angkor-warrior-women-found-expert-says-61781/ | title = Pre-Angkor Warrior Women Found, Expert Says | publisher = The Cambodia Daily | date=January 29, 2008 |accessdate=August 3, 2016 }}</ref>
== Archaeological significance ==
The high rates of traumatic lesions and weapons within the burials at Phum Snay suggest a society that values warriors. Fighting was an important part of life to the people, which could be indicative of increasing competition over access to exotic exchange items during the Iron Age.<ref name="domett" /> Furthering this idea is the general location of Phum Snay, right outside the Angkorian capital. Increasing competition over resources could have been the driving force behind the formation of a hierarchical society and organized state.<ref name="domett" /> The differences in morphological features between the human remains at Phum Snay and other modern Southeast Asian areas lends itself to the two-layer hypothesis. The people at Phum Snay were less affected by the substantial [[gene flow]] received by other areas of Southeast Asia.<ref name="mats" />

In [[quantum computing]], the ('''quantum''') '''threshold theorem''' (or '''quantum fault-tolerance theorem'''), proved by [[Michael Ben-Or]] and [[Dorit Aharonov]] (along with other groups),{{who|date=February 2012}} states that a quantum computer with a physical error rate below a certain threshold can, through application of [[Quantum error correction]] schemes, suppress the logical error rate to arbitrarily low levels. Current estimates put the threshold for the [[surface code]] on the order of 1%,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fowler|first=Austin G.|last2=Stephens|first2=Ashley M.|last3=Groszkowski|first3=Peter|date=2009-11-11|title=High-threshold universal quantum computation on the surface code|url=https://journals.aps.org/pra/pdf/10.1103/PhysRevA.80.052312|journal=Physical Review A|volume=80|issue=5|doi=10.1103/physreva.80.052312|issn=1050-2947|arxiv=0803.0272|bibcode=2009PhRvA..80e2312F}}</ref> though estimates range widely and are difficult to calculate due to the exponential difficulty of simulating large quantum systems. At a 0.1% probability of a depolarizing error, the surface code would require approximately 1,000-10,000 physical qubits per logical data qubit<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Campbell|first=Earl T.|last2=Terhal|first2=Barbara M.|last3=Vuillot|first3=Christophe|date=2017-09-13|title=Roads towards fault-tolerant universal quantum computation|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nature23460|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=549|issue=7671|pages=172–179|doi=10.1038/nature23460|issn=0028-0836|bibcode=2017Natur.549..172C}}</ref>, though more pathological error types could change this figure drastically.
== See also == * [[Quantum error correction]] * [[Physical and logical qubits]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
Books: * [https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/quantum-computation-and-quantum-information/01E10196D0A682A6AEFFEA52D53BE9AE Quantum Computation and Quantum Information] June 2012 (by Michael Nielsen and Isaac Chuang)
Papers from : https://journals.aps.org/ * [https://journals.aps.org/pra/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevA.96.052320 Blueprint for fault-tolerant quantum computation with Rydberg atoms] 14 Nov 2017 (Paywall with Abstract) * [https://journals.aps.org/pra/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevA.97.030301 Fault-tolerant quantum computation with nondeterministic entangling gates] 16 Mar 2018 (Paywall with Abstract)
Papers from : https://arxiv.org/ * [https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/9705031 Reliable Quantum Computers] 26 Aug 1997 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/9712048 Fault-tolerant quantum computation] 19 Dec 1997 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1006.4941 A note on threshold theorem of fault-tolerant quantum computation] 25 Jun 2010 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/quant-ph/0703230 Level Reduction and the Quantum Threshold Theorem] 11 Jul 2011 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.01686 Universal fault-tolerant quantum computation with Bacon-Shor codes] 4 May 2017 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.00294 High-threshold fault-tolerant quantum computation with analog quantum error correction] 6 Mar 2018 * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.00389 Efficient Preparation of Large Block Code Ancilla States for Fault-tolerant Quantum Computation] 22 Mar 2018
==External links== * [[Gil Kalai]]. [http://rjlipton.wordpress.com/2012/01/30/perpetual-motion-of-the-21st-century/ "Perpetual Motion of The 21st Century?"]. * [[Scott Aaronson]]. [http://www.scottaaronson.com/democritus/lec14.html "PHYS771 Lecture 14: Skepticism of Quantum Computing"]: ''«The entire content of the Threshold Theorem is that you're correcting errors faster than they're created. That's the whole point, and the whole non-trivial thing that the theorem shows. That's the problem it solves.»''

{{about|the [[Centimetre–gram–second system of units|CGS]] unit of [[equivalent dose]]|the historical equivalent of modern [[kerma (physics)|kerma]]|roentgen (unit)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Unit | bgcolour = | name = roentgen equivalent man | image = | caption = | standard = [[CGS]] units | quantity = [[Equivalent dose|Health effect of ionizing radiation]] | symbol = rem | dimension = | namedafter = [[Roentgen (unit)|roentgen]] | units1 = [[SI base unit]]s | inunits1 = [[metre|m]]<sup>2</sup>⋅[[second|s]]<sup>−2</sup> | units2 = [[SI derived unit]] | inunits2 = 0.01 [[Sievert|Sv]] }} The '''roentgen equivalent man''' (or '''rem''')<ref name=EPA2>{{cite web|title=RADInfo Glossary of Radiation Terms|publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency|website=EPA.gov|url=https://www.epa.gov/enviro/radinfo-glossary-radiation-terms|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Slate>{{cite|date=December 11, 2015|title=The First Line of Defense|first1=Jim|last1=Morris|first2=Jamie Smith|last2=Hopkins|work=Slate|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2015/12/nuclear_weapons_plants_are_killing_the_people_who_once_guarded_them_a_center.html|accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref> is an older, [[CGS]] unit of [[equivalent dose]], [[effective dose (radiation)|effective dose]], and [[committed dose]] which are measures of the health effect of low levels of [[ionizing radiation]] on the human body.
Quantities measured in rem are designed to represent the [[stochastic]] biological risk of ionizing radiation; primarily [[radiation-induced cancer]]. These quantities are derived from [[absorbed dose]], which in the CGS system has the unit [[rad (unit)|rad]] which is also an older unit. There is no universally applicable conversion constant from rad to rem; the conversion depends on [[relative biological effectiveness]] (RBE).
The rem has been defined since 1976 as equal to 0.01 [[sievert]], which is the more commonly used [[SI unit]] outside the United States. A number of earlier definitions going back to 1945 were derived from the [[roentgen unit]], which was named after [[Wilhelm Röntgen]], a German scientist who discovered [[X-ray]]s. The acronym is now a misleading historical artifact, since 1 [[roentgen (unit)|roentgen]] actually deposits about 0.96 rem in soft biological tissue, when all weighting factors equal unity. Older units of rem following other definitions are up to 17% smaller than the modern rem.
One rem carries with it a 0.05% chance of eventually developing cancer.<ref name=ICRP103 /> Doses greater than 100 rem received over a short time period are likely to cause [[acute radiation syndrome]] (ARS), possibly leading to death within weeks if left untreated. Note that the quantities that are measured in rem were not designed to be correlated to ARS symptoms. The [[absorbed dose]], measured in [[rad (unit)|rad]], is the best indicator of ARS.<ref name="remdef">''The Effects of Nuclear Weapons'', Revised ed., US DOD 1962</ref>{{rp|592–593}}
A rem is a large dose of radiation, so the '''millirem''' ('''mrem'''), which is one thousandth of a rem, is often used for the dosages commonly encountered, such as the amount of radiation received from medical x-rays and [[background radiation|background]] sources.
==Usage== The rem and millirem are [[CGS units]] in widest use among the American public, industry, and government.<ref name=EPA>{{cite web|title=Radiation: Risks and Realities|url=http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyPURL.cgi?Dockey=000003JH.txt|publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|accessdate=23 May 2012|author1=Office of Air and Radiation |author2=Office of Radiation and Indoor Air|page=2|format=PDF|date=May 2007|quote=In the United States, we measure radiation doses in units called rem. Under the metric system, dose is measured in units called sieverts. One sievert is equal to 100 rem.}}</ref> [[International System of Units|SI]] units are the norm outside of the United States, and they are increasingly encountered within the US in academic, scientific, and engineering environments.
The conventional units for dose rate is mrem/h. Regulatory limits and chronic doses are often given in units of mrem/yr or rem/yr, where they are understood to represent the total amount of radiation allowed (or received) over the entire year. In many occupational scenarios, the hourly dose rate might fluctuate to levels thousands of times higher for a brief period of time, without infringing on the annual total exposure limits. There is no exact conversion from hours to years because of leap years, but approximate conversions are: :1 mrem/h = 8766 mrem/yr :0.1141 mrem/h = 1000 mrem/yr The ICRP once adopted fixed conversion for occupational exposure, although these have not appeared in recent documents:<ref>{{cite book|title=Recommendations of the International Commission on Radiological Protection and of the International Commission on Radiological Units|year=1950|publisher=US Department of Commerce|url=http://www.orau.org/ptp/Library/NBS/NBS%2047.pdf|accessdate=14 November 2012|series=National Bureau of Standards Handbook|volume=47}}</ref> :8 h = 1 day :40 h = 1 week :50 week = 1 yr Therefore, for occupation exposures of that time period, :1 mrem/h = 2000 mrem/yr :0.5 mrem/h = 1000 mrem/yr
The US [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) strongly discourages Americans from expressing doses in rem, in favor of recommending the SI unit.<ref name=NIST>{{cite book|last1=Thompson|first1=Ambler|last2=Taylor|first2=Barry N.|title=Guide for the Use of the International System of Units (SI)|year=2008|publisher=[[National Institute of Standards and Technology]]|location=Gaithersburg, MD|url=https://www.nist.gov/pml/pubs/sp811/index.cfm|edition=2008|accessdate=28 November 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5YWY1pd2K?url=http://physics.nist.gov/Pubs/SP811/sec05.html|id=SP811|page=10|archivedate=12 June 2008|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The NIST recommends defining the rem in relation to the SI in every document where this unit is used.<ref name="fedreg63">{{cite journal|last=Hebner|first=Robert E.|title=Metric System of Measurement: Interpretation of the International System of Units for the United States|journal=Federal Register|date=1998-07-28|volume=63|issue=144|page=40339|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-1998-07-28/pdf/98-16965.pdf|accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref> For US industries and US firms that do not require the sole use of SI, however, the unit rem is often preferred.
== Health effects == Ionizing radiation has deterministic and stochastic effects on human health. The deterministic effects that can lead to [[acute radiation syndrome]] only occur in the case of high doses (> ~10 rad or > 0.1 Gy) and high dose rates (> ~10 rad/h or > 0.1 Gy/h). A model of deterministic risk would require different weighting factors (not yet established) than are used in the calculation of equivalent and effective dose. To avoid confusion, deterministic effects are normally compared to absorbed dose in units of rad, not rem.
Stochastic effects are those that occur randomly, such as [[radiation-induced cancer]]. The consensus of the nuclear industry, nuclear regulators, and governments, is that the incidence of cancers due to ionizing radiation can be modeled as increasing linearly with [[effective dose (radiation)|effective dose]] at a rate of 0.055% per rem (5.5%/Sv).<ref name="ICRP103">{{Cite book|title=The 2007 Recommendations of the International Commission on Radiological Protection|journal=Annals of the ICRP|year=2007|volume=37|series=ICRP publication 103|issue=2–4|url=http://www.icrp.org/publication.asp?id=ICRP%20Publication%20103|accessdate=17 May 2012|isbn=978-0-7020-3048-2|last1=Icrp}}</ref> Individual studies, alternate models, and earlier versions of the industry consensus have produced other risk estimates scattered around this consensus model. There is general agreement that the risk is much higher for infants and fetuses than adults, higher for the middle-aged than for seniors, and higher for women than for men, though there is no quantitative consensus about this.<ref name="peck">{{cite web |last1=Peck |first1=Donald J.|title=How to Understand and Communicate Radiation Risk |url=http://www.imagewisely.org/Imaging-Professionals/Medical-Physicists/Articles/How-to-Understand-and-Communicate-Radiation-Risk.aspx|publisher=Image Wisely |accessdate=18 May 2012 |author2=Samei, Ehsan}}</ref><ref name="UNSCEAR">{{cite book|first=United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation|title=Effects of ionizing radiation : UNSCEAR 2006 report to the General Assembly, with scientific annexes|year=2008|publisher=United Nations|location=New York|isbn=978-92-1-142263-4|url=http://www.unscear.org/unscear/en/publications.html|accessdate=18 May 2012}}</ref> There is much less data, and much more controversy, regarding the possibility of [[cardiac]] and [[teratogenic]] effects, and the modelling of [[internal dose]].<ref name="ECRR2010">{{cite book|last=European Committee on Radiation Risk|title=2010 recommendations of the ECRR : the health effects of exposure to low doses of ionizing radiation|year=2010|publisher=Green Audit|location=Aberystwyth|isbn=978-1-897761-16-8|url=http://www.euradcom.org/2011/ecrr2010.pdf|edition=Regulators'|editor=Busby, Chris|accessdate=18 May 2012|display-editors=etal|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721220541/http://www.euradcom.org/2011/ecrr2010.pdf|archivedate=21 July 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] (ICRP) recommends limiting artificial irradiation of the public to an average of 100 mrem (1 mSv) of effective dose per year, not including medical and occupational exposures.<ref name=ICRP103 /> For comparison, radiation levels inside the US [[United States Capitol]] are 85 mrem/yr (0.85 mSv/yr), close to the regulatory limit, because of the uranium content of the granite structure.<ref name="FUSRAP" >{{cite web|last=Formerly Utilized Sites Remedial Action Program|title=Radiation in the Environment|url=http://www.fusrapmaywood.com/projmain.html|publisher=US Army Corps of Engineers|accessdate=September 10, 2017}}</ref> According to the ICRP model, someone who spent 20 years inside the capitol building would have an extra one in a thousand chance of getting cancer, over and above any other existing risk. (20 yr × 85 mrem/yr × 0.001 rem/mrem × 0.055%/rem = ~0.1%) That "existing risk" is much higher; an average person would have a one in ten chance of getting cancer during this same 20-year period, even without any exposure to artificial radiation.
==History== The concept of the rem first appeared in the literature in 1945,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cantrill|first1=S.T|author2=H.M. Parker|title=The Tolerance Dose|date=1945-01-05|url=http://oai.dtic.mil/oai/oai?verb=getRecord&metadataPrefix=html&identifier=ADA322447|accessdate=14 May 2012|publisher=US Atomic Energy Commission|location=Argonne National Laboratory}}</ref> and was given its first definition in 1947.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Nucleonics|year=1947|volume=1|issue=2}}</ref> The definition was refined in 1950 as "that dose of any ionizing radiation which produces a relevant biological effect equal to that produced by one [[Roentgen (unit)|roentgen]] of high-voltage x-radiation."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Parker|first=H.M.|title=Tentative Dose Units for Mixed Radiations|journal=Radiology|year=1950|volume=54|issue=2|pages=257–262|doi=10.1148/54.2.257|pmid=15403708}}</ref> Using data available at the time, the rem was variously evaluated as 83, 93, or 95 erg/gram.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Elda E.|title=Units of Radiation and Radioactivity|journal=Public Health Reports|date=March 1952|volume=67|issue=3|pages=293–297|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2030726/pdf/pubhealthreporig01075-0073.pdf|accessdate=18 November 2012|doi=10.2307/4588064|pmc=2030726|pmid=14900367|jstor=4588064}}</ref> Along with the introduction of the [[rad (unit)|rad]] in 1953, the [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] (ICRP) decided to "continue" the use of the rem. The US [[National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measurements]] noted in 1954 that this effectively implied an increase in the magnitude of the rem to match the rad (100 erg/gram).<ref>{{cite book|title=Permissible Doses from External Sources of Radiation|publisher=US Department of Commerce|url=http://www.orau.org/ptp/Library/NBS/NBS%2059%20Addendum.pdf|accessdate=14 November 2012|page=31|date=24 September 1954|series=National Bureau of Standards Handbook|volume=59}}</ref> The ICRP officially adopted the rem as the unit of [[equivalent dose]] in 1962 to measure the way different types of radiation distribute energy in tissue, and began recommending values of [[relative biological effectiveness]] (RBE) for various types of radiation.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} In practice, the unit of rem was used to denote that an RBE factor had been applied to a number which was originally in units of rad or roentgen. In 1977 the rem was redefined by the ICRP as 0.01 [[sievert]] or 0.01 J/kg, with the intention that the sievert would come to replace the rem.
The [[International Committee for Weights and Measures]] (CIPM) adopted the sievert in 1980, but never accepted the use of the rem. The US [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) recognizes that this unit is outside the SI, but temporarily accepts its use in the US with the SI.<ref name="fedreg63" /> The rem remains in widespread use as an industry standard in the US.<ref>''Handbook of Radiation Effects'', 2nd edition, 2002, Andrew Holmes-Siedle and Len Adams</ref> The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission still permits the use of the units [[curie]], rad and [[rem (unit)|rem]] alongside SI units.<ref>{{cite book|title=10 CFR 20.1003|year=2009|publisher=US Nuclear Regulatory Commission|url=https://www.nrc.gov/reading-rm/doc-collections/cfr/part020/part020-1004.html}}</ref>

[[File:TaeTiSeo at Suncheon Bay Garden Expo International K-POP Concert 2013 03.jpg|alt=A 2013 live performance of Girls' Generation-TTS exemplifying Lolita-esque cuteness|thumb|A 2013 live performance of [[Girls' Generation-TTS]] exemplifying Lolita-esque cuteness]] [[K-pop]] started to become [[Sexualization|sexualized]] around the turn of the 21<sup>st</sup> century with its maturation<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/893686334|title=K-pop : popular music, cultural amnesia, and economic innovation in South Korea|last=John|first=Lie|publisher=|year=|isbn=9780520958944|location=Oakland, California|pages=|oclc=893686334}}</ref> due to globalization<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Gooyong|date=|title=Korean Wave{{!}} Between Hybridity and Hegemony in K-Pop’s Global Popularity: A Case of "Girls’ Generation’s" American Debut|url=https://ijoc.org/index.php/ijoc/article/view/6306|journal=International Journal of Communication|volume=11|pages=2367–2386|via=}}</ref> and the advent of music videos on social media/[[YouTube]].<ref name=":3">{{cite thesis|last=Song|first=Bohye|title=Seeing is Believing: Content Analysis of Sexual Content in Korean Music Videos|date=2016|publisher=Southern Utah University|url=https://www.suu.edu/hss/comm/masters/capstone/thesis/b-song.pdf|type=Masters}}</ref> Korean popular music was originally more conservative in the 1980s, took on the Japanese idol system during the 1990s,<ref name=":1" /> brought the western male gaze<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Puzar|first=Aljosa|date=|title=Asian Dolls and the Westernized Gaze: Notes on the Female Dollification in South Korea|url=|journal=Asian Women|volume=27(2)|pages=81-111|via=}}</ref> and Lolita culture in the 2000s,<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Kim|first=Yeran|date=December 2011|title=Idol republic: the global emergence of girl industries and the commercialization of girl bodies|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09589236.2011.617604|journal=Journal of Gender Studies|volume=20|issue=4|pages=333–345|doi=10.1080/09589236.2011.617604|issn=0958-9236|via=}}</ref> and morphed into a global phenomenon by the 2010s.<ref name=":1" /> Currently, [[Korean idol|K-pop idols]] are manufactured to optimize profit, making keen use of fan desires.<ref name=":1" /> In general, female and male idols follow normative femininity and masculinity, respectively, as defined by the South Korean patriarchal system, in conjunction with a globally desired façade.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Epstein|first=Stephen|last2=Joo|first2=Rachael M.|date=|title=Multiple Exposures: Korean Bodies and the Transnational Imagination|url=https://apjjf.org/2012/10/33/Stephen-Epstein/3807/article.html|journal=The Asia-Pacific Journal|volume=10(33)|pages=|via=}}</ref> Femininity is often defined by a suppressed [[Doll fetish|doll state]] conforming to [[Lolita (term)|Lolita]] ideals, presenting skinny bodies, long legs and perfect faces.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/488932704|title=The Lolita effect : the media sexualization of young girls and what we can do about it|last=Gigi|first=Durham, Meenakshi|date=2009|publisher=Overlook Press|isbn=9781590202159|oclc=488932704}}</ref> Masculinity follows a soft masculinity, or cosmopolitan masculinity, in that males are required to be strong and virile, but have soft features such as sweet personality traits or a cute face.<ref name=":8">{{cite thesis|last=Leung|first=Sarah|title=Catching the K-Pop Wave: Globality in the Production, Distribution, and Consumption of South Korean Popular Music|date=2012|publisher=Vassar College|url=https://digitalwindow.vassar.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1151&context=senior_capstone|type=Batchlors}}</ref> The manifestation of sexualization can be seen in all parts of the idol republic, but is normally seen in modern music videos, which have become more sexualized over the last decade.<ref name=":3" /> Additionally, it should be noted that female idols are often objectified more than male idols, something that is complementary to the patriarchal Korean culture.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Xi|last2=Rudolf|first2=Robert|date=|title=Does K-pop Reinforce Gender Inequalities? Empirical Evidence from a New Data Set|url=|journal=Asian Women|volume=33(4)|pages=27-54|via=}}</ref>
== Historical Context == The advent of modern K-pop arguably started in 1992, gained significant foothold by 1996 during the industrialization of K-pop, matured through the mid 2000s,<ref name=":1" /> and flourished in the 2010s.<ref name=":3" /> Albeit beauty is an ever-present ideal for Korean popular culture, these time periods represent shifts in beauty norms and K-pop ideals.<ref name=":1" /> The early 1990s brought a young, individualistic cuteness to the scene with stocky builds and chubby faces, following from the Korean beauty norms of the 1980s.<ref name=":1" /> Following the 1980s Japanese idol system, idol groups were generated in the late 1990s, often mimicking western boy bands with innocence and sunny dispositions, a product directed domestically. During this time a review committee censored all Korean music and music videos for sexual and other explicit content.<ref name=":3" /> The committee was disbanded in June 1996.<ref name=":3" /> After an economic crisis in 1997 and success of this domestic product outside South Korea, the innocence morphed into a more romantic and hipper image in the early 2000s, which presented the first major signs of sexualization.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> This transformation was aided by the increased use of music videos.<ref name=":3" /> By 2004 a new generation of K-pop was born, sex became prevalent in K-pop and idol-worshiping adolescents came into being.<ref name=":3" /> Within a decade, maturation of K-pop, driven by hyper-popularized music videos, propelled idols into a visual medium, thus transforming K-pop into the modern beauty standard of low body fat, well-toned muscles, and perfected body features.<ref name=":1" />
=== Globalization === The late 2000s brought K-pop into its modern era and introduced it to the international stage with the [[Korean Wave|Korean wave]] in Asia; the early 2010s bolstered K-pop to an international powerhouse with the global Korean wave. K-pop has always been influenced by western musical styles; however, many link its international success to the globalization caused by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) bailout period (during the 1997 South Korean economic crash) in South Korea's neoliberalization.<ref name=":2" /> Post-IMF South Korea has incorporated more Westernized (specifically, Americanized) culture into their products (i.e. exports) in order to prosper in international sales, thus pressing the popular music industry to become more westernized.<ref name=":2" /> Integration of westernization brought the western male gaze<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /> and the hypersexualization of products, especially in the popular music scene.<ref name=":2" /> Not only was the music itself altered to enhance exportability, but given the modern age of the music video, the performer was also altered.<ref name=":2" /> Combining this with Korea's male dominated society, one that currently ranks the near the bottom of the Global Gender Gap list for modernized societies (presenting the largest gender wage and working condition gaps), produces an overtly sexualized popular music market.<ref name=":9" /> Additionally, proliferation of K-pop allows for South Korea to enter into and even dominate the global “cultural war,” a concept tied to a battle for attention between the globalized cultures in the modern era. Thus, the government of South Korea encourages the use of K-pop to promote global recognition; however, because of the turbulence of popular culture, largely due to sexualization and exploitation, the government maintains no official backing of K-pop but restrains limiting what are allowable K-pop activities.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Saeji|first=CedarBough T.|date=December 2013|title=Juvenile Protection and Sexual Objectification: Analysis of the Performance Frame in Korean Music Television Broadcasts|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.18399/acta.2013.16.2.003|journal=Acta Koreana|volume=16|issue=2|pages=329–365|doi=10.18399/acta.2013.16.2.003|issn=1520-7412|via=}}</ref> Ergo, without official sponsorship of K-pop, the government unofficially helps it by reducing governmental constraints on it, especially for exported products.<ref name=":5" /> This allows the idols to become an unofficial representation of the South Korean culture, promoting cultural pride and building the nation into an “idol republic,” meaning that their image (i.e. bodies) belong to the state and represent the state's people.<ref name=":5" />
== Critical Issues == Sexualization in K-pop is mainly driven by economic reasoning and forces females into a globalized normative femininity and males into a globalized normative masculinity.
=== Economic Reasoning === Entering the world market to help globalize marketable Korean culture was only a byproduct of the economic conditions behind K-pop's evolution. Early K-pop was not well received critically, but its catchiness and localization enamored the masses.<ref name=":1" /> The success was noticed by a few business-oriented musicians that soon capitalized on the situation.<ref name=":1" /> Industrialization of K-pop occurred around the mid 1990s and its popularity grew.<ref name=":1" /> Maintaining localization while hybridizing (not assimilating) with Japan's idol methodology and American popular music stylings helped bolster success internally and as an export, albeit initially limited.<ref name=":1" /> The promising external success in conjunction with the diverse extant musical acts drove the music industry to facilitate portfolio diversification of their performing groups to maximize success and thus, profits. This meant optimized pandering to the most consumers. Such optimization lead to increasing numbers of performers per group, each individualized to suit different consumers’ tastes, perfecting the performances, and increasing attractiveness of the group to the different consuming cultures.<ref name=":1" /> Therefore, in the group itself there could be a proverbial “good,” “bad,” cute, or sexy member, while the whole group increased in attractiveness.<ref name=":1" /> Also, combining the desires of American culture for blatant sexiness,<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Unger|first=Michael A.|date=March 2015|title=The Aporia of Presentation: Deconstructing the Genre of K-pop Girl Group Music Videos in South Korea|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/jpms.12109|journal=Journal of Popular Music Studies|volume=27|issue=1|pages=25–47|doi=10.1111/jpms.12109|issn=1524-2226|via=}}</ref> Korean culture for [[aegyo]] (a compound of cute and lovable),<ref name=":4" /> and Japanese proclivity for [[kawaii]] and patriarchal Lolita ideas made a complex interplay of diverse satisfaction of fantastical desires.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> Following this logic, the music companies substantially invested monetarily and temporally in each performer in an effort to tailor them.<ref name=":1" /> A base level of attractiveness and skill is required to be considered as a performer.<ref name=":1" /> Years of subsequent training and discipline mold performers into what the public wants to see.<ref name=":1" /> They are disallowed from dating to maintain innocence,<ref name=":1" /> have a directed public life and persona (often sexualized or cute), shamed for gaining (or in some cases not losing) weight or not keeping their appearance up, may be required to go through plastic surgery for beautification,<ref name=":11" /> and are required to interact with fans in a desirable manner.<ref name=":1" /> All-in-all, K-pop is an industry driven by profit; subsequently, it treats its performers like well-molded commodities in order to adhere to consumer desires, often sexual in nature as in the westernized (male) gaze, and Lolita ideals.
=== Femininity === As the flagship cultural commodities of South Korea, female K-pop singers are expected to be sexy, strong, and independent, in conjunction with being a product for the patriarchal South Korean capitalist society, which wants them to be submissive, innocent, cute, and loveable.<ref name=":9" /> To maximize profit and success, the female stars must have the guise of ambiguity.<ref name=":5" /> Ultimately, the ambiguity results as a clash between virgin and whore, which nearly all groups have; however, some of them may be more biased to one side than the other.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Hazzan|first=Dave|date=|title=K-pop Chords of Sexism|url=http://www.davehazzan.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Herizons-v30n2-Fall16.pdf|journal=herizons|volume=30(2)|pages=44-45|via=}}</ref> South Korean ideals nominally press an aegyo image, or one that is “attractive and desirable beyond limits of intimate relations,” providing vulnerability to the idols but keeping them whimsical.<ref name=":4" /> To conform to the westernized male gaze, females take the part of an exotic sexual object,<ref name=":9" /> often under the dollified Asian motif, leading to thoughts of “convenient Asians.”<ref name=":4" /> Dollification is a construct of placing sexual desire upon a submissive and uncorrupted object of beauty, something common to Asia due to traditional gender roles and patriarchal structure, and applies exceptionally well to the surgically beautified K-pop females.<ref name=":4" /> Additionally, dolls are often associated with prostitution or sexual favors, something that idol singers can face when exploited by their employers.<ref name=":4" /> Dollification also plays into the Japanese desire for submissive kawaii: dolls are inherently cute and can be controlled at will, something that quenches the yearning for totally submissive females.<ref name=":4" /> Similarly, the concept of middle-aged Korean males seeing themselves as Samchon-fans (uncle-fans), or enduring uncles to the idols, has been argued as a facade to deny sexual desire when there is actually an underlying sexual gratification from the female bodies.<ref name=":5" /> This makes the female idol fill a Lolita role, one which fulfills a market need by supplying a male pedophilic fantasy of a young female with unconscious sexuality.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /> Consequently, girl (female) bodies have become a commodity and given implicit subjugation in the patriarchal structure, the consumption of such is acceptable.<ref name=":5" /> The females may present “girl power” given their high popularity status, but their pawn-like nature under the might of their parent companies keeps this a novelty, not a reality, via pacification.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /> The justified objectification of girl bodies in such an idol republic, where it is promoted economically and governmentally, makes it a Lolita republic, as argued by Yeran Kim.<ref name=":5" /> More simply, their bodies’ beauty can belong to a national collective.<ref name=":6" /> This beauty and femininity in image is prominently described as that of long legs with “honey thighs” and a perfect face and body, while showing ample skin; breasts are often sexualized but have only recently been presented as cleavage in K-pop due to the lack of cleavage shown in the general Korean culture.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":6" />
=== Masculinity === Paralleling female idols, male idols are also commodities to be sexualized in an effort to maximize profit and success. Given the rigorous patriarchal gender rolls existing in Korea, the males are normally subjected to the requirement of Korean masculinity, but to optimize for diverse target audiences, they often present vulnerabilities, forming a non-Korean masculinity.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/840865016|title=Korean masculinities and transcultural consumption Yonsama, Rain, Oldboy, K-Pop idols|last=Sun.|first=Jung,|date=2011|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|oclc=840865016}}</ref> Korean (hegemonic) masculinity can consist of patriarchal authority, traditional Confucian masculinity, and violence.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/46240370|title=Under construction : the gendering of modernity, class, and consumption in the Republic of Korea|last=Laurel.|first=Kendall,|date=2002|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=0824824075|oclc=46240370}}</ref> Contradictorily, non-Korean masculinity contains a range of metrosexuality from charming to chic.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> This dichotomy forces bands to be muscular, potent, and appearing sexually virile, while injecting cuteness and innocence into their presentation, creating a transnational “soft masculinity” and “global metrosexual masculinity.”<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> Both a soft masculinity called “flower boys,” and a harder masculinity, called “beast idols,” appear in K-pop groups, but even the hardest K-pop masculinity maintains a globalized cuteness.<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/column/k-pop-generation/article/2013/10/22/Kpop_Men_Gender_Roles_Soy/|title=Men in K-Pop: From “Flower Boys” to “Beast-dols”|last=Soyoung|first=Kim|date=October 22, 2013|website=The Harvard Crimson|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170325192647/https://www.thecrimson.com/column/k-pop-generation/article/2013/10/22/Kpop_Men_Gender_Roles_Soy/|archive-date=March 25, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The key features of K-pop masculinity are muscular (often nude) torsos and cute actions/personalities.<ref name=":6" /> Well-defined muscles, albeit a falsity, can be considered a sign of both individual phallic power in response to feministic movements and nationalistic female desires.<ref name=":6" /> This is exemplified by a “body price” (momgap) notion that equates the sexiness of a male body to its (and his) worth,<ref name=":6" /> with “chocolate abs” being the most desirable trait.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":6" /> Emasculated actions/personalities are often subtly employed to diversify the K-pop masculine act,<ref name=":6" /> as previously stated, but have occasionally been stressed by some to help break gender norms.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.soompi.com/article/1079057wpp/8-k-pop-idols-challenging-gender-norms-korea|title=8 K-Pop Idols Who Are Challenging Gender Norms In Korea|last=heytoto|first=|date=November 28, 2017|website=soompi|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, removing masculinity as a whole is ineffective, as noted by a Korean studies professor Oh Ingyu of Korea University, Seoul, “[a] male star without well-defined muscles, six-pack abs and a handsome smile won’t go far.”<ref name=":12" /> As stated by Sarah Leung “[the K-pop industry’s] ultimate goal? To sell an image to the screaming girls in the crowd.”<ref name=":8" />
== Manifestation == Sexualization of the popular Korean music market takes place in many forms: pushing sexy and attractive performers, conforming the performers to fan fantasies, and presenting sexualized songs or music videos.<ref name=":5" />
=== Dollification === Dollification can be observed in a Japanese quote on the introduction to a performance by [[Girls' Generation|Girls’ Generation]] “I was shocked by their amazingly beautiful legs. The dance was as if dolls were dancing and it was wondrous.”<ref name=":6" /> Likewise, employers utilized doll images for advertisement. The idol [[G.NA]]’s body measurements were a hot topic with fans, so her employer promoted her by juxtaposing her with mannequins during photoshoots while calling her body “the mannequin body” because of her small face, large breasts, and small waist.<ref name=":4" /> This representation of a dollified human parallels Girl's Generation's “Gee” music video, in which the members are acting as mannequins in a shop's window that soon come alive or [[Girl's Day|Girl's Day]]’s music video for “Tilt my Head,” in which the members act like doll factory automata producing self-similar dolls that magically come alive (both also following the “coming alive” narrative).<ref name=":4" /> Countering the description of a perfect doll image is the group Piggy Dolls, consisting of three heavier set females, engendering diversity in body image.<ref name=":4" />
=== Female idol bodies === In general, K-pop idol bodies are heavily regulated by their employers; in fact, female bodies are not considered their own, as presented by a snarky statement by a member of [[Super Junior]], "[Girls’ Generation] can't get hurt without permission. Their bodies aren't their own. They're treasures of the nation."<ref name=":6" /> Consequently, female idols need to conform to image norms. A normative male gaze desires long legs, something Girls’ Generation has in multitudes, as exemplified by a Japanese nickname “The Beautiful Legs Group,” and has even spawned a Japanese pornographic film based on their legs.<ref name=":6" /> Similarly, bodily perfection is a requirement of the profit-driven entertainment kingpins. An out of shape body can be put through training to lose weight, such as done by the Piggy Dolls for a comeback,<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://seoulbeats.com/2013/09/piggy-girls-making-comeback-im-smiling/|title=Piggy Dolls Are Making a Comeback: Why I’m Not Smiling|last=Gabrielle|first=|date=September 9, 2013|website=seoulbeats|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180406102526/http://seoulbeats.com:80/2013/09/piggy-girls-making-comeback-im-smiling|archive-date=April 6, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> who lost a total of 56 kg.<ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=https://www.generasia.com/wiki/Piggy_Dolls|title=Piggy Dolls|last=|first=|date=|website=generasia|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180329203009/http://www.generasia.com:80/wiki/Piggy_Dolls|archive-date=March 29, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Often encountered is a trainee with a good body but bad face, and fixing this imperfection is often accomplished by their employer enforcing mandatory plastic surgery (with the exception of [[YG Entertainment|YG entertainment]], who prohibits plastic surgery); not getting a mandatory surgery can mean career failure.<ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-04-25/k-pop-s-gross-double-standard-women|title=K-pop’s Gross Double Standard for Women|last=Volodzko|first=David|date=April 25, 2016|website=Public Radio International|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908120956/https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-04-25/k-pop-s-gross-double-standard-women|archive-date=September 8, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Although any surgery is dangerous and can have complications,<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Elfving-Hwang|first=Joanna|date=June 16, 2013|title=Cosmetic Surgery and Embodying the Moral Self in South Korean Popular Makeover Culture|url=https://apjjf.org/2013/11/24/Joanna-Elfving-Hwang/3956/article.html|journal=The Asia-Pacific Journal|volume=11(24)|pages=|via=}}</ref> it is very common to have small aesthetic plastic surgeries and moderately common to have semi-reconstructive surgeries, to the point that a large number of K-pop stars have undergone some form of plastic surgery. Common modifications are a double-eyelid addition, rhinoplasty, chin shaving,<ref name=":21">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/934514703|title=Behind South Korean cosmetic surgery : its historical causes and its intertwined relationship with Korean pop culture|last=Yuqing.|first=Wang,|date=2015|isbn=9781321989939|oclc=934514703}}</ref> and muscular reshaping (legs mainly).<ref name=":6" /> There are some idols who have openly admitted to aesthetic surgeries, such as Miryo of [[Brown Eyed Girls]], who had a double eyelid surgery, Goo Hara of [[Kara (South Korean band)|KARA]] with an eyelid alteration, and Jessi who had breast implants, rhinoplasty, and surgery on her eyelids.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/03/28/8-idols-whove-discussed-their-plastic-surgery|title=8 Idols Who've Discussed Their Plastic Surgery|last=|first=|date=March 28, 2018|website=SBS|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107072347/https://www.sbs.com.au/popasia/blog/2018/03/28/8-idols-whove-discussed-their-plastic-surgery|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Some even act as spokespeople for plastic surgery offices, such as G.Na with a statement of “[c]ome and become more beautiful” for Dr. Jong Phil.<ref name=":23">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/the-k-pop-plastic-surgery-obsession/276215/|title=The K-Pop Plastic Surgery Obsession|last=Stone|first=Zara|date=May 24, 2013|website=The Atlantic|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027132247/https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/05/the-k-pop-plastic-surgery-obsession/276215/|archive-date=October 27, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> However, most artists keep enhancements private, so there is great conjecture of K-pop idols that may have had plastic surgery, including even the biggest names, such as members of Girls’ Generation<ref name=":24">{{Cite web|url=https://plastytalk.com/truth-behind-kpop-snsd-plastic-surgery/|title=The Truth Behind K-pop SNSD Plastic Surgery|last=K.|first=Sandy|date=April 6, 2016|website=PlastyTalk.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171213120816/https://plastytalk.com/truth-behind-kpop-snsd-plastic-surgery/|archive-date=December 3, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and [[Hyuna|Huyna]],<ref name=":25">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ranker.com/list/kpop-female-idols-before-and-after-plastic-surgery/onlysuy|title=K-pop Female Idols Before and After Plastic Surgery|last=|first=|date=|website=Ranker|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170830111928/http://www.ranker.com:80/list/kpop-female-idols-before-and-after-plastic-surgery/onlysuy|archive-date=August 30, 2017|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> among others. With so much conjecture, some singers, such as Lee Hyori and Jang Yoon-Ju, amongst other famous Koreans, have even gone so far as to medically prove they have had no breast augmentation done to defend themselves.<ref name=":26">{{Cite web|url=https://www.koreaboo.com/lists/haters-accused-female-idols-breast-implants-proved-them-wrong/|title=Haters Accused These Female Idols Of Breast Implants…So They Proved Them Wrong|last=|first=|date=March 16, 2018|website=Koreaboo|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107073117/https://www.koreaboo.com/lists/haters-accused-female-idols-breast-implants-proved-them-wrong/|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> On the other hand, the group Six Bomb has embraced plastic surgery and has even made a song and music video called “Getting Pretty After” extolling it.<ref name=":27">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/39302637/K-pop-band-six-bomb-celebrate-plastic-surgery-with-before-and-after-videos|title=K-Pop band Six Bomb 'celebrate' plastic surgery with before and after videos|last=|first=|date=March 17, 2017|website=BBC|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180428090721/http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/newsbeat/article/39302637/k-pop-band-six-bomb-celebrate-plastic-surgery-with-before-and-after-videos|archive-date=April 28, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In fact, their manager, Kim Il-woong, has openly admitted to all the members getting surgical augmentations to their faces and breasts.<ref name=":27" /> This type of candor and idolization system of K-pop has actually affected much of the youth and general Korean culture to desire plastic surgery in an effort to emulate their favorite stars.<ref name=":23" /> This fact has helped drive South Korea to have the most cosmetic surgeries per capita out of anywhere in the world.<ref name=":6" /> However, challenging these norms are idols such as [[Amber Liu (singer)|Amber]] from [[F(x) (band)|f(x)]], who wears male shorts, cuts her hair short, and even jokes about her “missing breasts.”<ref name=":16" />
=== Male idol bodies === Males are likewise subjected to rigorous body standards, with a requirement to keep up their “body price”<ref name=":6" /> while balancing their soft masculinity.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":13" /> The singer Rain is the embodiment of effeminate hyper-masculinity.<ref name=":28">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/900162636|title=The Korean wave : Korean media go global|last=compilation|first=Kim, Youna, editor of|date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415712781|oclc=900162636}}</ref> His well-defined abs and upper muscular body, often seen naked and oiled (or wet), is contrasted to his cute and young face.<ref name=":28" /> He is described as having “an angelic face and a killer body” or “a man’s body with a boy’s face.”<ref name=":28" /><ref name=":29">{{Cite journal|last=Shin|first=Hyunjoon|date=December 2009|title=Have you ever seen theRain? And who’ll stop theRain?: the globalizing project of Korean pop (K-pop)|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14649370903166150|journal=Inter-Asia Cultural Studies|volume=10|issue=4|pages=507–523|doi=10.1080/14649370903166150|issn=1464-9373|via=}}</ref> Rain is exemplary of the image required: a shirtless, muscular male, with some grounding cute elements. To keep this image, rigorous training is required, normally employing trainers and intense daily workout routines.<ref name=":6" /> As with their female counterparts, there is sometimes a need for plastic surgery. Similarly, conjecture exists for who has undergone surgery, but again, some idols have explicitly stated their surgical augmentations. For example, Kwanghee of [[ZE:A]] had eyelid, nose, and forehead alterations, Kim Heechul from Super Junior had eyelid alterations and fixed remnants of a past broken nose with surgery, and his co-star Kyuhyun (of Super Junior) had a double eyelid surgery following his parents example.<ref name=":22" /> It is important to note some of the gender norm challengers. Kim Heechul of Super Junior hosts a show “Lipstick Prince” to cover makeup for both genders, Ren from [[NU'EST|NU’EST]] modeled dresses, skirts, and other similar clothing, Lee Hong Ki of [[F.T. Island|FTISLAND]] both wears and promotes his nail art, Jo Kwon is a queer culture advocate and crossdresser, and Hansol enjoys makeup and has admitted to being non-heterosexual.<ref name=":16" />
=== Sexualization in YouTube music videos === {{See also|List of banned K-pop videos}} Given the popularization of K-pop through visual social media such as YouTube,<ref name=":1" /> many fans would most recognize sexualization in music videos or recorded performances. The advent of music videos to help brand recognition brought a survival-of-the-fittest attitude to the images of the artists; that is, the sexier artists survived.<ref name=":3" /> Therefore, sex was commercialized to capitalize on human reproductive nature, allowing sexualization to flourish.<ref name=":3" /> Given the liberalization of sex, sexual content has increased in K-pop music videos; therefore, a video content analysis was performed by Bohye Song by taking MelOn Hot 100 chart listings of the most popular Korean music videos of 2004, 2005, 2014, and 2015 to analyze their sexual content and increases over time.<ref name=":3" /> Content observed were sexual innuendos, sexual acts, and provocative clothing while the results were broken down into four parts of changes in physical affection, provocative dress, suggestiveness, and gender variance.<ref name=":3" /> It was found that displayed physical affections did not change on average, but implicit sex increased, sexual suggestiveness increased, provocative clothing increased, and female lead singers showed a significant increase in provocative display.<ref name=":3" /> This means that there is a significant increase in the display, mainly through clothing, of sexualized females and some males, but there is not much of an increase in sexual acts (two people in contact) depicted.<ref name=":3" /> This can be exemplified with modern music videos. Examples of K-pop music videos with revealing clothing on a female singer include “Marionette” by Stellar, “Roll Deep” by Hyuna, “Ring My Bell” by Girl's Day, “Wild” by [[Nine Muses (band)|Nine Muses]], “Wiggle Wiggle” by [[Hello Venus]], “Like a Cat” by [[AOA (band)|AOA]], “Butt” by I-Ren, and “Dr. Feel Good” by [[Rania (band)|BP RaNia]], among many others.<ref name=":30">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/K-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-female-edition|title=K-Pop idols' most revealing outfits [Female Edition]|last=|first=|date=May 22, 2017|website=allkpop|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114013918/https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/k-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-female-edition|archive-date=January 14, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The female singers sported short skirts, short shorts, cleavage, tight clothing, et cetera.<ref name=":30" /> Correspondingly, male singers have worn see-through shirts and pants, extremely short shorts, and even corsets or skimpy dresses (in drag).<ref name=":31">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/K-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-male-edition|title=K-Pop idols' most revealing outfits [Male Edition]|last=|first=|date=May 24, 2017|website=allkpop|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180115014357/https://www.allkpop.com/article/2017/05/k-pop-idols-most-revealing-outfits-male-edition|archive-date=January 15, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Complementary to these are banned-from-broadcast videos, which include, but are not limited to, “MOMMAE” by [[Jay Park]], due to overtly sexualized females; “Abracadabra” by Brown Eyed Girls, for being sexually suggestive; “Mirotic” by [[TVXQ]], for body exposure and explicit language; “One More” by [[Fiestar|FIESTAR]], due to sexual imagery; both “Vibrato” and “Marionette” by [[Stellar (South Korean band)|Stellar]], for sexually suggestive dancing and clothing; “Touch Me” by Ivy, for sexual imagery and suggestive lyrics; “Joker” by [[Dal Shabet]], for sexual choreography; “Shower Later” by Gary, due to sexual innuendos and mature themes; and “Bae Bae” by [[Big Bang (South Korean band)|BIGBANG]], for sexual innuendos.<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=https://www.koreaboo.com/stories/10-K-pop-mvs-that-were-deemed-too-sexy-for-tv/|title=10 K-Pop MVs that have been banned for being “Too Sexual”|last=|first=|date=January 6, 2017|website=Koreaboo|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181107074515/https://www.koreaboo.com/stories/10-K-pop-mvs-that-were-deemed-too-sexy-for-tv/|archive-date=November 7, 2018|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Lastly, the transition from innocent to sexualized can be shown by Girls’ Generation music videos.<ref name=":11" /> Their video for “[[Gee (Girls' Generation song)|Gee]]” in 2009 maintained schoolgirl innocence, then their video for “[[Oh! (Girls' Generation song)|Oh!]]” in 2010 kept their innocence but added on a prelude to their dark side at the end when it pitted the innocent schoolgirl cheerleaders against sexier, shadowy versions of themselves.<ref name=":11" /> Finally, their 2011 video for “[[The Boys (Girls' Generation song)|The Boys]]” replaced innocence with mature sexiness.<ref name=":11" />
== Controversies == Sexualization has a multitude of implications, causing controversies. One key controversy involves the disproportionate sexualization and objectification of females in comparison to males, perpetuating the patriarchal ideal of South Korea.
=== Gender inequalities === Both male and female K-pop idols are taken advantage of and objectified; however, females appear to have a disproportionate amount of sexism pitted against them.<ref name=":9" /> Females are subjected to the western male gaze, dollification, and being considered exotic and submissive for their masculine fans in a patriarchal society.<ref name=":9" /> Femininity is desired to coincide with the neo-Confucian patriarchal social structure so as to maximize profit; idols are normally forced into this definition in conjunction with Korea's inherently well-defined roll for women.<ref name=":9" /> Additionally, being below Japan's Global Gender Gap Index and aligned with Muslim-majority countries’, South Korea's Global Gender Gap Index represents the general poor state of gender equality in South Korea.<ref name=":9" /> Xi Lin and Rober Rudolf conducted a survey of 6,317 K-pop fans from 100 countries to determine the egalitarianism of the K-pop consumers.<ref name=":9" /> Their study found that more K-pop indulgence correlated to less egalitarianism, with this being most notable in already gender stratified countries.<ref name=":9" /> Similarly, the stratification of genders in Korea is actually aided by the government and its patriarchal capitalism, and vice-versa.<ref name=":9" /> That is, sexism and sexualization in K-pop support the success of South Korea's patriarchal capitalism, forcing norms of gender inequalities and the sexual objectification of female K-pop idols.<ref name=":9" />

'''Shuly Rubin Schwartz''' is the Irving Lehrman Research Associate Professor of American Jewish History and Walter and Sarah Schlesinger Dean of Graduate and Undergraduate Studies at The [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]] (JTS).
Schwartz is a graduate of [[Barnard College]] and the [[Jewish Theological Seminary of America]].<ref>http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/author/schwartz-shuly</ref> She wrote her Ph.D. dissertation at JTS under the direction of [[Ismar Schorsch]].
Her first published book was ''The Emergence of Jewish Scholarship in America: The Publication of the "[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]"''. Her second book, ''The Rabbi's Wife: The Rebbetzin in American Jewish Life'', was awarded a 2006 [[National Jewish Book Award]].

The '''Society for Pentecostal Studies''' (SPS) is an American [[Learned society|scholarly association]] of biblical scholars, theologians, and others who are members of [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal churches]] or are involved in the [[Charismatic Renewal]]. It was founded in 1970. The members of the Society consider themselves responsible for recording the history and developing the theology of these grassroots movements that have influenced Christianity worldwide.
== Overview == SPS was first envisioned by three classical Pentecostals, Dr. [[William W. Menzies]] of the [[Assemblies of God]], Dr. [[H. Vinson Synan]] of the [[International Pentecostal Holiness Church]], and Dr. [[Horace Ward]] of the [[Church of God (Cleveland, Tennessee)|Church of God]]. The original requirement for membership was adherence to the statement of faith of the [[Pentecostal Fellowship of North America]]. However, because [[nontrinitarian]]s and others were unable to sign the statement for doctrinal reasons, this requirement was eventually eliminated.
The purpose of the Society, as defined on its website, is to provide a scholarly forum in which to interpret the [[Pentecostal]] movement as well as "to stimulate, encourage, recognize, and publicize the work of Pentecostal and Charismatic scholars and scholars of Pentecostalism; to study the implications of Pentecostal theology in relation to other academic disciplines, seeking a Pentecostal world-and-life view; and to support fully, to the extent appropriate for an academic society, the following statement of purposes:
-To encourage fellowship and facilitate co-ordination of effort among Pentecostal believers throughout the world.
-To demonstrate to the world the essential unity of Spirit-baptized believers, fulfilling the prayer of the Lord Jesus Christ, “That they all may be one” (John 17:21).
-To cooperate in an endeavor to respond to the unchanging commission of the Lord Jesus, to carry His message to all people of all nations.
-To promote courtesy and mutual understanding, “endeavoring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace, until we all come in the unity of the faith” (Ephesians 4:3, 13).
-To afford prayerful and practical assistance to any Pentecostal body in need of such.
-To promote and maintain the scriptural purity of the Society by Bible study and prayer.
-To uphold and maintain those Pentecostal truths, “most surely believed among us” (Luke 1:1)."<ref>http://www.sps-usa.org/</ref>
The Society holds annual conferences. The organization, which began as a scholarly branch of classical Pentecostalism, is now [[ecumenical]], with over 500 members from all major [[Christian denomination]]s. For many years, the Society has hosted the meetings of the Roman Catholic/Pentecostal dialogue (see [[Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity]]).
