'''Vaginal photoplethysmography''' ('''VPG''', '''VPP''') is a [[photoplethysmogram|technique using light]] to measure the [[vasocongestion|amount of blood]] in the walls of the [[vagina]]. The device that is used is called a vaginal [[photometer]].
==Use== The device is used to try to obtain an objective measure of a woman's [[sexual arousal]]. There is an overall poor correlation (r = 0.26) between women's self-reported levels of desire and their VPG readings.<ref name=Chivers2010>{{cite journal | year = 2010| title = Agreement of Self-Reported and Genital Measures of Sexual Arousal in Men and Women: A Meta-Analysis | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 39 | issue = 1| pages = 5–56 | pmc=2811244 | pmid=20049519 | doi=10.1007/s10508-009-9556-9 |vauthors=Chivers ML, Seto MC, Lalumière ML, Laan E, Grimbos T }}</ref>
==Instrument== The instrument used in the procedure is called vaginal [[photometer]]. The device has a clear shell, inside of which is a light source and a [[photocell]], which senses reflected light. The use of the device is done with the assumption that the more light that is scattered back, and that the photocell senses, the more blood is in the walls of the vagina.<ref name=Jannsen2007/>
The output of the VPG can be filtered into two types of signals, which have different properties. The [[direct current]] signal is a measure of vaginal blood volume (VBV) and reflects the total blood volume in the [[vagina|vaginal tissues]].<ref name="Hatch">Hatch, J. P. [“Vaginal photoplethysmography: Methodological considerations”],”Archives of Sexual Behavior, 8, 357–374”, 1979</ref> {{Update inline|date=February 2018}} The [[alternating current]] signal is a measure of vaginal pulse amplitude (VPA) and reflects the pressure change within the [[blood vessel]]s of the vaginal wall associated with each heartbeat.<ref name="Hatch" /> While changes in VBV occur in response to sexual and anxiety-inducing stimuli, changes in VPA only occur in response to sexual stimuli.<ref>Laan, E., Everaerd, W., & Evers, A. [http://repository.ubn.ru.nl/bitstream/handle/2066/21166/21166.PDF?sequence=1 “Assessment of female sexual arousal: Response specificity and construct validity”], “Psychophysiology, 32, 476–485”, 1995</ref>{{Update inline|date=February 2018}}
VPA is defined as the [[amplitude|peak-to-trough amplitude]] of the vaginal pulse wave. It is calculated by subtracting the means of all troughs from the means of all peaks experienced during stimulus presentation.VPA lacks an absolute scale of measurement; each unit of change (mV) does not correspond directly with a physiological change. Since VPA does not have a standard unit of measurement, it is difficult for researchers to make between-participant comparisons.<ref name=Chivers2010/>
==History== VPG was first introduced in the 1960s by Palti and Berovici, who affixed a light source and photosensitive cell onto a [[speculum (medical)|gynecological speculum]] and recorded vaginal pulse waves.<ref name=Jannsen2007>{{cite book|last1=Jannsen|first1=Erick|last2=Prause|first2=Nicole|last3=Geer|first3=James H.|editor1-last=Cacioppo|editor1-first=John T.|editor2-last=Tassinary|editor2-first=Louis G.|editor3-last=Berntson|editor3-first=Gary|title=Handbook of Psychophysiology|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781139461931|page=254|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Handbook_of_Psychophysiology.html?id=E7hRKwVBXb4C|language=en|chapter=Chapter 11: The Sexual Response}}</ref><ref name=Molenkamp>{{cite web|last1=Molenkamp|first1=Bert|title=SexLab - Equipment & Instruments - Vaginal Photoplethysmography|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~sexlab/ei-vp-uvaprobe.html|publisher=Indiana University|accessdate=10 February 2018|date=2016}}</ref><ref>Palti, Y. & Bercovici, B. [“Photoplethysmographic study of the vaginal blood pulse”], “American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology, 97, 143–53”, 1967</ref> Sintchak and Geer improved on the device in the 1970s by using a vaginal probe which became the common instrument to measure vaginal blood flow.<ref name=Jannsen2007/><ref name=Molenkamp/><ref name=Chivers2010/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sintchak|first1=G|last2=Geer|first2=JH|title=A vaginal plethysmograph system.|journal=Psychophysiology|date=January 1975|volume=12|issue=1|pages=113-5|pmid=1114202}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Labial thermistor clip]] * [[Clitoral photoplethysmograph]] * [[Penile plethysmograph]]
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:The science and art of midwifery (1891) (14579471209).jpg |thumb|150px|Vaginal rugae are illustrated in this 1891 medical textbook image]] '''Vaginal rugae''' are structures of the vagina that are transverse ridges formed out of the supporting tissues and [[vaginal epithelium]] in females.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/rugae+of+vagina|title=Rugae of vagina|last=|first=|date=|work=TheFreeDictionary.com|access-date=2018-02-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Some conditions can cause the disappearance of vaginal rugae and are usually associated with childbirth and prolapse of pelvic structures. The rugae contribute to the resiliency and elasticity of the vagina and its ability to distend and return to its (nearly) previous state.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blausen.com/en/video/stratified-squamous-epithelium-vaginal-lining-and-rugae/|title=Stratified Squamous Epithelium: Vaginal Lining and Rugae|website=blausen.com|accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5s7jDVQkCfoC&pg=PA98#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Clinical Anatomy: An Illustrated Review with Questions and Explanations|last=Snell|first=Richard S.|date=2004|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9780781743167|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3eQZhs4PwrYC&pg=PA307&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIOjAD#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Evaluation of the Sexually Abused Child: A Medical Textbook and Photographic Atlas|last=Heger|first=Astrid M.|last2=Emans|first2=S. Jean|last3=Muram|first3=David|date=2000-09-07|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199747825|language=en}}</ref> These structures not only allow expansions and an increase in surface area of the [[vaginal epithelium]], they provide the space necessary for the vaginal microbiota. The shape and structure of the rugae are supported maintained by the [[lamina propria]] of the vagina and the anterior and posterior rugae.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dartmouth.edu/~anatomy/Histo/lab_6/female/DMS184/popup.html|title=Vaginal epithelium|last=|first=|date=|website=www.dartmouth.edu|publisher=Dartmouth College|access-date=2018-02-15}}</ref>
The anterior and posterior columnae rugae are transverse vaginal support structures between which the transverse rugae exist. The cross section of the vagina normally forms a shape that resembles the letter 'H' due to these structures.<ref name="Hafez">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8DxCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIUzAI#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Atlas of Human Reproduction: By Scanning Electron Microscopy|last=Hafez|first=E. S.|last2=Kenemans|first2=P.|date=2012-12-06|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9789401181402|language=en}}</ref>
Vaginal rugae disappear in those with an [[Hypoestrogenism|estrogen deficiency]] and those women who are older.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Whiteside JL, Barber MD, Paraiso MF, Walters MD | title = Vaginal rugae: measurement and significance | journal = Climacteric | volume = 8 | issue = 1 | pages = 71–5 | date = March 2005 | pmid = 15804734 | doi = 10.1080/13697130500042490 }}</ref> The rugae can disappear with anterior vaginal wall prolapse which can occur when supports to the portion located between the vagina and bladder are damaged and the bladder bulges into the vaginal lumen. Vaginal self-examination includes visualizing the presence of vaginal rugae.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.emedicinehealth.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=129410|title=Vaginal Self-Examination (VSE): Healthwise Medical Information on eMedicineHealth|work=eMedicineHealth|access-date=2018-02-15}}</ref> Anatomists identified rugae of the vagina as early as 1824.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/0266373.nlm.nih.gov|title=Observations on those diseases of females which are attended by discharges : illustrated by copper-plates of the diseases, &c.|last=Clarke|first=Charles Mansfield|date=1824|publisher=Philadelphia : Carey and Lea|others=U.S. National Library of Medicine}}</ref>
== Development == The appearance and presence of vaginal rugae change over the life span of females and are associated with hormonal cycles, [[estrogens]], childbirth, puberty and menopause. During gynecological examination of [[prepubescent]] girls, rugae can be visualized.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sugar|first=Naomi|last2=Graham|first2=Elinor|date=2006|title=Common Gynecologic Problems in Prepubertal Girls|url=https://depts.washington.edu/hcsats/cd/march2008/Articles/Sugar%20Graham%20Common%20Problems%20in%20Prepubertal%20Gyn.pdf|journal=Pediatrics in Review|volume=27|pages=|via=}}</ref> The vaginal rugae change after [[menopause]]. In some older women the rugae are present but become flattened and difficult to see.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r6q94qWGkRoC&pg=PA429&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Ostergard's Urogynecology and Pelvic Floor Dysfunction|last=Bent|first=Alfred E.|last2=Cundiff|first2=Geoffrey W.|last3=Swift|first3=Steven E.|date=2008|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9780781770958|language=en}}</ref> In others, the rugae tend to disappear.<ref name=":0" />
== Clinical considerations == Other structures can be present on the vaginal wall though most of the time these can be differentiated from rugae.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> [[Vaginal cysts]] can be small protrusions into the vagina that can be felt or palpated by a clinician. Vaginal inclusion cysts can appear as small bumps and can develop after childbirth.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/001509.htm|title=Vaginal cysts: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia|website=medlineplus.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-02-17}}</ref> Other small structures or protrusions can be Gardner duct cysts, patches of endometrial tissue, and benign tumors.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kondi-Pafiti|first=A.|last2=Grapsa|first2=D.|last3=Papakonstantinou|first3=K.|last4=Kairi-Vassilatou|first4=E.|last5=Xasiakos|first5=D.|date=2008|title=Vaginal cysts: a common pathologic entity revisited|journal=Clinical and Experimental Obstetrics & Gynecology|volume=35|issue=1|pages=41–44|issn=0390-6663|pmid=18390079}}</ref> These cystic structures can obliterate the rugae and is a clue to their presence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jayaprakash|first=Sheela|last2=M|first2=Lakshmidevi|last3=G|first3=Sampath Kumar|date=2011-07-04|title=A rare case of posterior vaginal wall cyst|url=http://casereports.bmj.com/content/2011/bcr.02.2011.3804|journal=BMJ Case Reports|language=en|volume=2011|pages=bcr0220113804|doi=10.1136/bcr.02.2011.3804|issn=1757-790X|pmid=22693290|pmc=3132834}}</ref> The absence of vaginal rugae seen in the normal vagina of a healthy women may be an indication of a prolapsed bladder (cycstocele) or rectocele.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y5cYRhGJsOsC&pg=PA41&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Vaginal Surgery for Incontinence and Prolapse|last=Zimmern|first=Philippe E.|last2=Haab|first2=Francois|last3=Chapple|first3=Christopher R.|date=2007-12-09|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781846283468|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> An [[enterocele]], or bulging of the [[Gastrointestinal tract|bowel]] into the vagina can also cause vaginal rugae disappear.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9KuCMWWG8BcC&pg=PA1028&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Key Topics in Critical Care, Second Edition|last=Craft|first=T. M.|last2=Parr|first2=M. J. A.|last3=Nolan|first3=Jerry P.|date=2004-11-10|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781841843582|language=en}}</ref> The absence of vaginal rugae may also be an indicator of [[pelvic organ prolapse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y5cYRhGJsOsC&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41&dq=rugae+vaginal&source=bl&ots=_aB0zfSH_H&sig=4bxHBjHfuWtdR361qDUs0m--GNA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAwZmh5KfZAhVNhq0KHf6WCX04ChDoAQhVMAc#v=onepage&q=rugae+vaginal&f=false|title=Vaginal Surgery for Incontinence and Prolapse|last1=Zimmern|first1=Philippe E.|last2=Haab|first2=Francois|date=9 December 2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|accessdate=15 February 2018|last3=Chapple|first3=Christopher R.|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name="walters2013">{{Cite book|title=Urogynecology and Reconstructive Pelvic Surgery|last=Walters|first=Mark D|last2=Karram|first2=Mickey M|publisher=Saunders|year=2014|isbn=978-0323113779|location=|pages=326–341}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GahMzaKgMKAC&pg=PA326&lpg=PA326&dq=Vaginal+fascia&source=bl&ots=mWTqBGn5ty&sig=NvSxzV5itQoi26FRJm44FAJs4F8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijwIXG3L3ZAhVBnuAKHZAeAlY4ChDoAQhAMAQ#v=onepage&q=Vaginal%20fascia&f=false|title=Glenn's Urologic Surgery|last=Graham|first=Sam D.|last2=Keane|first2=Thomas E.|last3=Glenn|first3=James Francis|date=2010|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|year=|isbn=9780781791410|location=|pages=238|language=en}}</ref> Vaginal rugae disappear in those with an [[Hypoestrogenism|estrogen deficiency]].<ref name=":1" /><ref name="pmid20042564">{{cite journal | vauthors = Mac Bride MB, Rhodes DJ, Shuster LT | title = Vulvovaginal atrophy | journal = Mayo Clin. Proc. | volume = 85 | issue = 1 | pages = 87–94 | date = January 2010 | pmid = 20042564 | pmc = 2800285 | doi = 10.4065/mcp.2009.0413 }}</ref>
== Childbirth == Vaginal rugae can disappear during the second stage of labor.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KknXFtQr5O4C&pg=PA88&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIPzAE#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Multidisciplinary Management of Female Pelvic Floor Disorders|last=Chapple|first=Christopher R.|date=2006-01-01|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=0443072728|language=en}}</ref> After a vaginal birth the rugae are not visible and the walls of the vagina are smooth. By the third week postpartum the vagina has become much smaller and the rugae begin to reform on the vaginal walls. Six weeks after birth, the rugae have returned to approximately the same size as they were before the birth. The number of rugae after childbirth decreases.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PmTJ5Qbql6UC&pg=PA296&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIRDAF#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Obstetrics, Gynaecology and Women's Health|last=O'Connor|first=Vivienne|last2=Kovacs|first2=Gabor|date=2003-10-07|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521818933|language=en}}</ref> Those women who have not given birth, the rugae are more prominent than in those who have given birth multiple times.<ref name="Hafez"/>

[[File:Roman Catholic Elementary School- Life at St Joseph's, Upper Norwood, 1943 D14456.jpg |thumb|right|200px|A music teacher leading a music ensemble in an elementary school in 1943]] '''Women in music education''' describes the role of [[Women in music|women musicians, conductors, teachers and educational administrators]] in [[music education]] at the [[elementary school]] and [[secondary education]] levels. While [[music critic]]s argued in the 1880s that "...women lacked the innate creativity to compose good music" due to "biological predisposition",<ref name="parlorsongs.com">{{cite web|url=http://parlorsongs.com/issues/2002-9/thismonth/feature.php |title=Women Composers In American Popular Song, Page 1 |publisher=Parlorsongs.com |date=1911-03-25 |accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref> later, it was accepted that women would have a role in [[music education]], and they became involved in this field "...to such a degree that women dominated music education during the later half of the 19th century and well into the 20th century."<ref name="parlorsongs.com"/> "Traditional accounts of the history of music education [in the US] have often neglected the contributions of women, because these texts have emphasized bands and the top leaders in hierarchical music organizations." <ref name="Sandra Wieland Howe 2015">Dr. Sandra Wieland Howe. "Women Music Educators In The United States: A History", in ''GEMS (Gender, Education, Music, and Society)'', the on-line journal of Gender Research in Music Education. Vol 8, No 4 (2015)</ref> When looking beyond these bandleaders and top leaders, women had many music education roles in the "...home, community, churches, public schools, and teacher-training institutions" and "...as writers, patrons, and through their volunteer work in organizations."<ref name="Sandra Wieland Howe 2015"/>
Despite the limitations imposed on women's roles in music education in the 19th century, women were accepted as [[kindergarten]] teachers, because this was deemed to be a "private sphere". Women also taught music privately, in girl's schools, Sunday schools, and they trained musicians in school music programs. By the turn of the 20th century, women began to be employed as music supervisors in elementary schools, teachers in [[normal school]]s and professors of music in universities. Women also became more active in professional organizations in music education, and women presented papers at conferences.
A woman, Frances Clarke (1860–1958) founded the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] in 1907. While a small number of women served as President of the Music Supervisors National Conference (and the following renamed versions of the organization over the next century) in the early 20th century, there were only two female Presidents between 1952 and 1992, which "[p]ossibly reflects discrimination." After 1990, however, leadership roles for women in the organization opened up. From 1990 to 2010, there were five female Presidents of this organization.<ref name="slideshare.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.slideshare.net/bigbadbariguru/a-historical-view-of-women-in-music-education-careers |title=A historical view of women in music education careers |publisher=Slideshare.net |date=2012-07-05 |accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref> Women music educators "outnumber men two-to-one" in teaching general music, choir, private lessons, and keyboard instruction.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> More men tend to be hired as for band education, administration and jazz jobs, and more men work in colleges and universities.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> According to Dr. Sandra Wieland Howe, there is still a "[[glass ceiling]]" for women in music education careers, as there is "stigma" associated with women in leadership positions and "men outnumber women as administrators."<ref name="slideshare.net"/>
==Notable individuals== *[[Julia Crane]] (1855–1923) (1855–1923) was an [[music education in the United States|American music educator]] who set up a school, the [[Crane School of Music]] in [[Potsdam (town), New York|Potsdam, New York]], which was the first school specifically for the training of public school music teachers.<ref>Campbell and Klinger, pg. 276</ref> She is among the most important figures in the history of American music education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://post.queensu.ca/~grime/v3n1.html|accessdate=May 19, 2008|title=Women in American Music Education: How Names Mentioned in History Books are Regarded by Contemporary Scholars|work=MENC Sessions (April 1994)|author=Carolyn Livingston}}</ref> Crane was a student of [[Manuel García (baritone)|Manuel García]].<ref>"Garcia's Method of Breathing", Werner's Magazine, December 1889, 270.</ref> Crane was inducted into the Music Educators Hall of Fame in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.menc.org/information/histinfo/Historicalinfohall.html|title=Music Educators Hall of Fame Honorees|accessdate=May 19, 2008|publisher=Music Educators Hall of Fame}}</ref> As of 2015, the Crane School of Music is one of three schools which make up the [[State University of New York at Potsdam|State University of New York (SUNY) at Potsdam]]. It has 630 undergraduate and 30 graduate students and a faculty of 70 teachers and professional staff. *Frances Clarke (1860–1958) was a music supervisor in the Milwaukee Public School system. She founded the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] in 1907. It was an organization of American music educators dedicated to advancing and preserving music education as part of the core curriculum of schools in the [[United States]]. In 2011, it was renamed the National Association for Music Education and it had more than 130,000 members.<ref>{{cite web|title= Press Reslease: Building on the Past to Shape the Future of Music Education|url=http://www.nafme.org/news/view/press-release-building-on-the-past-to-shape-the-future-of-music-education/|year=2011|work=NAfME official website|publisher=NAfME|accessdate=11 September 2011}}</ref> and in March 2012, Professor Glenn Nierman was elected President-Elect of NAfME.<ref>{{cite web|title= New NAfME President Seeks to Restore Trust|url=http://sociomusicology.blogspot.com/2012/03/new-nafme-president-seeks-to-restore.html|year=2012|work=Sociomusicology blog|publisher=David Hebert|accessdate=13 March 2012}}</ref> *Elsie Shaw (1866–1962) was a music supervisor in St. Paul, Minnesota. She supervised and taught elementary school teachers and conducted choirs and orchestras. She encouraged the offering of music education at the high school level.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *[[Satis N. Coleman|Satis Coleman]] (1878–1961), who taught at Teachers College, Columbia University and Lincoln Lab School in the 1920s and 30s, created a popular method for teaching music creatively.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1017/S0265051700007622 | volume=7 | title=A Music Education Pioneer – Dr Satis Naronna Barton Coleman | journal=British Journal of Music Education | page=123}}</ref> She published many books that were foundational to music education, ethnomusicology, and out-of-school music scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://elibrary.ru/item.asp?id=5743978|title=SATIS N. COLEMAN (1878-1961): HER CAREER IN MUSIC EDUCATION|website=Elibrary.ru|accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> Her pedagogy involved field trips, instrument construction (often of non-Western instruments), and improvisation, and her philosophy had spiritual and ecological aspects.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/0027432115590182 | volume=102 | title=Satis Coleman—A Spiritual Philosophy for Music Education | journal=Music Educators Journal | pages=56–61}}</ref> *Mabelle Glenn (1881-1969) was a music supervisor in Bloomington, Indiana and a director of music in Kansas City, Missouri. She wrote [[music appreciation]] books and music textbooks. She was President of the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Supervisors National Conference]] from 1928–1930.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Lilla Pitts (1884–1970) graduated from [[Northwestern University]]. She was a faculty member of the teacher's college at [[Florida State University]]. She served as President of the [[National Association for Music Education|Music Educators National Conference]] (the new name for the Music Supervisors National Conference) from 1942–1944.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Marguerite Hood (1903–1992) graduated from the [[University of Southern California]]. She was a supervisor of music for Montana, a faculty member at the [[University of Montana]], the [[University of Southern California]] and the [[University of Michigan]]. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1950–1952. She was the first woman to be appointed as chair of the ''[[Music Educators Journal]]''.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Frances Andrews (1908–1976) received her Masters and Doctorate from [[Pennsylvania State University]], where she was a faculty member from 1943 to 1973. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1970–1972.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Mary Hoffman (1926–1997) graduated with a bachelor's degree in science from [[Lebanon Valley College]] and a Masters from [[Columbia Teachers College]]. She was a music supervisor in Milwaukee and Philadelphia. She gave graduate courses at Columbia Teachers College, [[Temple University]] and the [[University of Illinois]]. She wrote and contributed to textbooks. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1980–1982.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Dorothy Straub (born 1941) graduated with Bachelors and master's degrees in music education from [[Indiana University]]. She was the music coordinator for Fairfield Public Schools in Connecticut. She was a violinist in two orchestras. She was given awards from the [[American String Teachers Association|ASTA]] and the National School Orchestra Association. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1992–1994.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Carolynn Lindeman (born 1940) graduated from [[Oberlin College Conservatory of Music]], the Mozarteum Academy, [[San Francisco State University]] and [[Stanford University]], where she received her [[Doctor of Musical Arts]]. She was a professor at San Francisco State University from 1973 to 2005. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1996–1998. She edited the "Strategies for Teaching" series. She "[a]cknoledge[d] discrimination in academia."<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *June Hinckley (1943–2007) graduated with a PhD from [[Florida State University]]. She was a music and fine arts supervisor in Brevard County in Florida. She wrote articles on music education. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 1998–2000.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Lynn Brinckmeyer received her PhD from the [[University of Kansas]]. She was an Associate Professor and Director of Choral Music Education at [[Texas State University]]. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 2006–2008.<ref name="slideshare.net"/> *Barbara Geer graduated from the [[University of North Carolina]]. She was a music consultant for a school system in North Carolina. She was President of the Music Educators National Conference from 2008–2010.<ref name="slideshare.net"/>

{{Infobox academic|name=Zoe Todd|image=Zoe Todd at Walrus Talks.jpg|birth_date=1983|residence=Canada, United States|nationality=Canadian, Métis|occupation=anthropologist, professor, artist|home_town=Edmonton, Alberta|awards=Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation Scholarship|education=University of Alberta, University of Aberdeen|influences=Vanessa Watts, Leroy LittleBear, Kim TallBear, Natasha Myers, Donna Haraway, Val Napoleon, Loretta Todd|discipline=anthropology, sociology, Indigenous studies, science & technology studies, human-animal studies|workplaces=Carleton University, Banff Centre, Yale University|influenced=Kim TallBear, Natasha Myers, Donna Haraway|principal_ideas=Indigenizing the anthropocene}}
'''Zoe Todd''' is a [[Métis]] anthropologist and scholar of [[Indigenous studies]], [[Animal studies|human-animal studies]], [[science and technology studies]] and the [[Anthropocene]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://carleton.ca/socanth/people/todd-zoe/|title=Todd, Zoe|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.psu.edu/story/451229/2017/02/16/penn-state-women%E2%80%99s-studies-graduate-organization-conference-set-feb-24-25|title=Penn State Women’s Studies Graduate Organization conference set for Feb. 24-25|last=|first=|date=|work=Penn State News|access-date=2018-11-16|language=en}}</ref> She is an assistant professor in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at [[Carleton University]] and a Presidential Visiting Fellow at [[Yale University]] during the 2018-19 academic year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://faculty.yale.edu/diversity/presidential-visiting-fellows-2018-19|title=Presidential Visiting Fellows for 2018-19|last=|first=|date=|website=Yale University Faculty|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref>
== Early Life == Todd was born to a [[Métis]] father and white settler mother in Edmonton, Alberta, in 1983. She credits her father, an artist, Gary Todd's engagement with his Métis heritage as an influential factor in her scholarship; especially his art and his knowledge of fish and wildlife of the Canadian prairies<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://activehistory.ca/2016/01/conversations-with-my-fathers-paintings-writing-my-relations-back-into-the-academy/|title=Conversations with my Father’s paintings: writing my relations back into the academy|date=2016-01-11|work=ActiveHistory.ca|access-date=2018-10-12|language=en-CA}}</ref>. Todd is a descendant of William Todd, a 19th century surgeon from the British Navy<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cmagazine.com/issues/126/rethinking-aesthetics-and-ontology-through-indigenous-law-on-the|title=Rethinking Aesthetics and Ontology through Indigenous Law: On the work of Val Napoleon and Loretta Todd|last=Todd|first=Zoe|date=2015|website=C Magazine|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref>. She received her BSc in biological sciences and an MSc in rural sociology from the [[University of Alberta]] and her PhD in social anthropology from the [[University of Aberdeen]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://zoesctodd.wordpress.com/academic-training/|title=Academic training|date=2013-07-28|work=Dr. Zoe S.C. Todd|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref>. She received the prestigious [[Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation]] Scholarship in 2011 for her PhD research.
== Research == Todd's research concerns human-animal relations, in particular, human-fish, relationships in the context of [[Settler colonialism]] in Canada<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Todd|first=Zoe|date=2014|title=Fish pluralities: Human-animal relations and sites of engagement in Paulatuuq, Arctic Canada|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7202/1028861ar|journal=Études/Inuit/Studies|language=en|volume=38|issue=1-2|pages=217|doi=10.7202/1028861ar|issn=0701-1008}}</ref>. She is an assistant professor at [[Carleton University]]'s Department of Sociology and Anthropology<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://carleton.ca/socanth/people/todd-zoe/|title=Todd, Zoe|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref>. She is most well-known for her work on decolonizing anthropology<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Todd|first=Zoe|date=2016|title=An Indigenous Feminist's Take On The Ontological Turn: ‘Ontology’ Is Just Another Word For Colonialism|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/johs.12124|journal=Journal of Historical Sociology|language=en|volume=29|issue=1|pages=4–22|doi=10.1111/johs.12124|issn=0952-1909|via=}}</ref> and Indigenous perspectives on the Anthropocene<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acme-journal.org/index.php/acme/article/view/1539|title=On the Importance of a Date, or, Decolonizing the Anthropocene|last=Davis|first=Heather|authorlink=|last2=Todd|first2=Zoe|date=2017|website=www.acme-journal.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-11|}}</ref><ref>Todd, Z. (2015). Indigenizing the Anthropocene. Pp. 241- in ''Art in the Anthropocene: Encounters Among Aesthetics, Politics, Environment and Epistemology''. Heather Davis and Etienne Turpin, editors. Open Humanities Press.</ref>. She has been a faculty at the [[Banff Centre|Banff Centre for Arts & Creativity]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.banffcentre.ca/events/zoe-todd-conversation|title=Zoe Todd|website=www.banffcentre.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>. In 2018, she became a Visiting Assistant Professor at [[Yale University]]'s Program in History of Science & Medicine<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hshm.yale.edu/people/zoe-todd|title=Zoe Todd|last=|first=|date=|website=Yale Program in History of Science & Medicine|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-11|}}</ref>.
She has been featured on the CBC<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/radio/outintheopen/political-anger-architects-1.3825756/web-exclusive-polite-no-more-1.3825965|title=Web exclusive: Polite No More {{!}} CBC Radio|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/aboriginal/crowd-sourced-video-project-aims-to-make-trc-report-more-accessible-1.3123525|title=Truth and reconciliation report hits YouTube in #ReadTheTRCReport {{!}} CBC News|work=CBC|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-US}}</ref>, Walrus Talks<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewalrus.ca/fish-and-indigenous-law/|title=Fish and Indigenous Law|work=The Walrus|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en-CA}}</ref>, Buzzfeed<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/laurenstrapagiel/this-might-be-the-most-powerful-way-to-take-in-the-truth-and#.vt0w1LNxz|title=This Is The Most Powerful Way To Experience The Truth And Reconciliation Report|work=BuzzFeed|access-date=2018-10-11|language=en}}</ref>, Rabble<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rabble.ca/blogs/bloggers/campus-notes/2016/11/canlit-heavyweights-letter-support-steven-galloway-leaves-rape-s|title=CanLit heavyweights' letter in support of Steven Galloway leaves rape survivors out in the cold {{!}} rabble.ca|website=rabble.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref> and many others on Indigenous issues, feminism, environment, colonialism, capitalism and rape culture. Todd is also known for her artistic work, which are mostly inspired by the freshwater fish of Alberta<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://society6.com/zoestodd|title=ZoeSTodd's Store {{!}} Society6|website=Society6|access-date=2018-10-11}}</ref>. In 2018, she was interviewed by [[Sarain Fox]] on her work on Indigenous perspectives on the Anthropocene for the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]] podcast ''Into the Anthropocene''<ref>{{Citation|title=Episode 03 - Whose earth is it anyway? Decolonizing the Anthropocene|url=https://soundcloud.com/agotoronto/episode-03-whose-earth-is-it-anyway-decolonizing-the-anthropocene|language=en|access-date=2018-10-12}}</ref>.
== Selected Works == '''Academic works:'''
* Todd, Zoe. (2018). ‘Refracting colonialism in Canada: fish tales, text, and insistent public grief.’ Mark Jackson, editor. ''Coloniality, Ontology, and the Question of the Posthuman.'' Routledge Press''.'' * Todd, Z. (2015). Indigenizing the Anthropocene. Pp. 241-254 in ''Art in the Anthropocene: Encounters Among Aesthetics, Politics, Environment and Epistemology''. Heather Davis and Etienne Turpin, editors. Open Humanities Press. * Davis, Heather and Zoe Todd. (2017). On the importance of a date, or, decolonizing the Anthropocene. ''ACME: An International Journal for Critical Geographies''. * Todd, Zoe. (2017). Fish, Kin, and Hope: tending to water violations in amiskwaciwâskahikan and Treaty Six Territory. ''Afterall: a Journal of Art, Context and Inquiry'' 43(1): 102-107. * Todd, Zoe. (2016). ‘How do you teach about the layered colonial realities that mould a Canadian city?’ (commentary). Aboriginal Policy Studies 6(1): 90-97. (Invited piece) * Todd, Z. (2016). ‘An Indigenous Feminist’s Take on the Ontological Turn: ‘Ontology’ is just another word for colonialism’. ''Journal of Historical Sociology'' 29(1): 4-22. * Todd, Z. (2014). ‘Fish pluralities: Human-animal relations and sites of engagement in Paulatuuq, Arctic Canada’. ''Etudes/Inuit/Studies'' 38(1-2): 217-238.
'''Other writing:'''
* Todd, Z. (2015). Rethinking Aesthetics and Ontology through Indigenous Law: On the work of Val Napoleon and Loretta Todd. ''C Magazine'' 126: 10-17. * Todd, Z. (2014). Creating citizen spaces through Indigenous soundscapes. ''Spacing Magazine''. Published 01 October 2014 <nowiki>http://spacing.ca/national/2014/10/01/creating-citizen-spaces-indigenous-soundscapes/</nowiki> * Todd, Z. (2013). On Scottish Independence — a Metis Perspective. ActiveHistory.ca. <nowiki>http://activehistory.ca/2013/12/on-scottish-independence-a-metis-perspective/</nowiki> * Todd, Z. (2013). “Remembering Indigenous Edmonton: a journey through plants”. ''Spacing Edmonton''. <nowiki>http://spacing.ca/edmonton/2013/04/04/remembering-indigenous-edmonton-a-journey-through-plants/</nowiki>
